questions.neutral: Timing's good - not too busy, huh?

hobby.message: Political literature still keeping you up?
Origami's still better than meds, huh?
Urban exploration still your kind of therapy?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I explore the city's underground. It's a different world down there.
neutral_answer: Not bad. Quiet suits me, especially after a long night.
I mess with old hardware, out in the tunnels sometimes.
Lately, too many people poking around. Makes repairs less peaceful.
Blackout week stirred up all sorts—had to cut things short.
Yeah, not many folks out. Easier to think.
Urban exploration’s my thing. Utility tunnels, forgotten substations.
Used to be only rats and old cabling for company.
These days, others show up—since that puzzle app craze.
Last time, wasn’t sure if I was fixing or hiding.
Perfect crowd for my taste. I do urban exploration as a hobby.
I dig through old service tunnels. Sometimes repair, sometimes just looking.
Picked up a knack from my state days—comes in handy.
Recently, after that blackout, I ran into folks chasing those app riddles.
Wasn’t just me in the dark. Makes the hobby more complicated.
Had to keep my distance, for a change.
Just right. I spend most nights in the empty tunnels or sealed data rooms.
Urban exploring keeps me sane. Sometimes I patch things up, sometimes I drink and wander.
Been doing it since before the BCI made everyone paranoid.
Used to be I only ran into leaks or stray cats.
Now, with that blackout and those puzzle caches, there’s a crowd down there.
Saw a group find one of the erased names lists—nearly tripped over them.
Hobby’s not so secret anymore, not with all this unrest.
Quiet’s good. Fits me. I haunt the tunnels—urban exploration is my obsession, honestly.
After hours, there’s nothing like the old chiller rooms, gears and ghost circuits.
Picked it up back when I worked for the state. Never could kick the habit.
I like finding what’s been left behind—tools, records, sometimes a bit of history.
Before, I’d barter found parts, drink in the silence, no trouble at all.
Ever since the blackout and that puzzle app, it’s crowded down there—kids, resistance, all sorts poking around.
The last run, I stumbled on a group opening a cache with erased names. Could’ve been bad.
Feels less like a hobby, more like a battleground. Still, can’t seem to stay away.
hobby_answer: Yeah. Still like poking around where the city forgets itself.
Mostly just finding old cabling now, nothing special.
Keeps me moving, keeps the mind sharp.
Some folks getting curious lately, but that’s none of my business.
Quiet is harder to find these days, that’s all.
That’s me. Still wandering tunnels with a bottle in the coat.
I find broken things, sometimes fix them. Sometimes just watch.
Lately, more people showing up—never used to be that way.
Recent app craze, you know, brought odd sorts underground.
I try to stay clear, just looking for scraps, not crowds.
Makes things less peaceful, that’s for sure.
Right. Urban exploring, homebrew to keep the cold out.
Old pipes, server vaults, even sealed junctions—every spot has history.
Usually it’s just me and the echo. Calms me down.
After the blackout, been running into folks with puzzle apps.
They follow clues, end up crowding my old haunts.
Found a cache once—names of wiped people, would you believe.
Hobby’s less private now, not always by choice.
Yeah, that’s my ritual: dark tunnels, flask, and a bit of luck.
I know every maintenance crawlspace in Blocks 14 through 22.
Used to be only stray cats and me down there.
Since Halden died, the city’s glitched, and folks scavenger-hunt for secrets now.
Saw a group find a cache marking erased workers—never happened before.
I keep my head down, but it’s risky.
There’s real tension, even under the city.
Feels like the tunnels are alive again, but not just for me.
Exactly. Homebrew and the old wires—never needed anything fancier.
Started exploring when I left state work—freedom and quiet, that's all I wanted.
I map every access point, keep tabs on old security patches.
Now every curious soul with a puzzle app is down there, hunting what’s hidden.
The blackout drew a crowd, but these new caches—they rattled people.
Found one myself: proof of vanished colleagues, wiped like they never existed.
Feels like my shadow hobby became everybody’s business overnight.
Saw fear and hope in the same tunnel, which is new.
Can’t say if it’s good or bad, but the city’s different now.
